Editorial changes have been made throughout the IRM and include:
Reorganizing the IRM without changing any substantive content or meaning so that tax (TEs) can easily ﬁnd needed information
Adding or correcting references and citations and adding more links to the forms that are in the IRM
Updating information subject to frequent changes such as: tax years, line numbers on forms, and tax season limit updates.
Updating organizational terms, titles, and acronyms that are relevant to International Notice Review tax examiners.
Converting text to tables so that TEs can more readily identify and access changes.
IRM 3.38.147 dated November 10, 2021 (effective January 1, 2022) is superseded. This IRM incorporates IRM Procedural Update (IPU) 22U0323, issued March 02, 2022.

) Purpose: This section provides IMF Notice Review personnel with for reviewing CP notices that have been selected by the Notice Review Pro- cessing System (NRPS). Reviews are conducted with the goal of improving both the accuracy and quality of information the IRS send to taxpayers. The Notice Review process helps to ensure the information received by is complete and correct and taxpayers do not receive an erroneous refund erroneous balance due notice. ) Under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights get-help/taxpayer-rights/ taxpayers have rights that apply throughout their ings with the IRS. The right to be informed means taxpayers are entitled to clear explanation of laws and IRS procedures in all tax forms, instructions, publications, notices, and correspondence. Thus, notices should be reviewed to ensure they are written in plain language, provide clear explanations of IRS decisions about a taxpayer’s account, and provide clear instructions for what a taxpayer needs to do. Taxpayers also have the right to a fair and just tax system, which means they can receive assistance from the Taxpayer cate Service (TAS) if they are experiencing ﬁnancial difficulty or the IRS has not resolved their issues properly or timely through normal channels. information about TAS on correspondence will help protect this right. have the right to expect the tax system to consider facts and circumstances that might affect their underlying liabilities, ability to pay, or ability to provide information timely. ) Under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR)https://www.taxpayeradvocate.irs.gov/ get-help/taxpayer-rights/ taxpayers have rights that apply throughout their deal- ings with the IRS. The right to be informed means taxpayers are entitled to clear explanation of laws and IRS procedures in all tax forms, instructions, publications, notices, and correspondence. Thus, notices should be reviewed to ensure they are written in plain language, provide clear explanations of any IRS decisions about a taxpayer’s account, and provide clear instructions for what a taxpayer needs to do. Taxpayers also have the right to a fair and just tax system, which means they can receive assistance from the Taxpayer Advo- cate Service (TAS) if they are experiencing ﬁnancial difficulty or the IRS has not resolved their issues properly or timely through normal channels. Including information about TAS on correspondence will help protect this right. Taxpayers have the right to expect the tax system to consider facts and circumstances that might affect their underlying liabilities, ability to pay, or ability to provide information timely.

) Alien - Any person who is not a U.S. citizen or U.S. National. For income purposes, aliens are classiﬁed as Resident or Nonresident. (
) Bona Fide Residence - A residence established in a foreign country or countries for an uninterrupted period which includes an entire taxable year includes part of the tax year of the return. (
) Domicile - A ﬁxed or permanent place of living for an indeﬁnite length of A domicile can be different from the taxpayer’s residence. (
) Dual-Status -Refers to aliens who are both resident aliens and nonresident aliens of the U.S. within the same tax year. (

) Effectively Connected Income - All income, gain, or loss that is derived in nection with the conduct of a trade or business within the United States. generally includes compensation received for personal services performed the U.S. by a nonresident alien. (
) Excludable Income - Any income that can be omitted from taxable income such as, Form
exclusions, exclusions due to applicable tax treaty sions and other exclusions provided by the Internal Revenue Code. (
) Foreign Tax Treaties - bilateral treaties entered into by the United States foreign country generally with the purpose of avoiding double taxation and venting tax evasion. (
) Fulbright Grant - A grant under the Mutual Educational and Cultural Act of
It can be received for teaching, research duties, and/or talents abroad by U.S. students and foreign students. (

) Green Card Test - One of the tests for determining whether an alien is a resident alien. A lawful permanent resident of the U.S. (Green Card Holder) any time during the calendar year, is a resident alien for Federal income purposes. A taxpayer is a lawful permanent resident, if that individual has granted the privilege of residing permanently in the United States as an
page immigrant in accordance with the immigration laws. Resident status is to continue unless it is rescinded or administratively or judicially determined have been abandoned . (
) Nonresident Alien - An alien who is temporarily residing in the U.S., a alien who has abandoned permanent residence in the U.S. or an alien who has never been in the U.S. (
) Non-Effectively Connected Income - Income which is not effectively with a U.S. trade or business. (

) Physical Presence Test - A test to determine if a taxpayer qualiﬁes for the foreign earned income exclusion. Generally, the taxpayer must be physically present in a foreign country or countries for a minimum of
month period that includes part of the current tax year. (
) Principal Residence - Usually the home in which a taxpayer resides for the majority of the tax year. (
) Resident Alien - An alien individual who is either a lawful permanent resident (i.e., meets the “Green Card Test”) or who meets the substantial presence for the calendar year. (

) Substantial Presence Test- A test applied in determining if an alien is a U.S. resident alien for tax purposes. Generally, an individual meets the substantial presence test if the individual was in the United States for at least
days during the current calendar year and was present in the United States for at least
days during the current year and the two preceding calendar years, calculated by counting all the days of the current year,

of the days in the second preceding year. Note: For purposes of the substantial presence test, individuals under F, J, M, Q visas are treated as “exempt individuals” and they do not count days of temporary presence in the United States. However, there are limitations on the length of time that an individual will be an “exempt individual ”for purposes of the substantial presence test. Internal Revenue Manual #

Fixed Determinable, Annual or Periodical Income (FDAP) - If the resident alien earns U.S. source FDAP that is not Effectively Connected Income (ECI), the U.S. may impose a statutory

percent gross basis tax (unless the item of income is exempt or subject to reduced rate of withholding pursuant to an IRC Section or applicable income tax treaty). Effectively Connected Income (ECI) - If a nonresident alien conducts a U.S. trade or business, then the U.S. may tax the person’s income as effectively connected with the U.S. trade or business. ECI is taxed at the same graduated tax rates that apply to U.S. taxpayers. However, some types of ECI may be exempt (in the whole or in part) from tax under an applicable income tax treaty.

M Visa The “M” Visa is issued only to alien students who have already been accepted as registered students by an established vocational or other recognized nonacademic institution, other than in language programs. Q Visa The “Q” Visa is issued to alien students whose employment or training affords the opportunity for cultural sharing with the American public. They are allowed to work in the United States for a speciﬁc em- ployer in an approved cultural exchange program. The employer must the petitioner through whom the alien obtained the “Q” Visa. ) The United States has income tax treaties with a number of countries. Under these treaties, residents of foreign countries are (if eligible) taxed at a rate, or are exempt from U.S. income taxes on certain items of income received from sources within the United States. These reduced rates and exempt amounts vary among countries and speciﬁc items of income. The “resident” is generally deﬁned under the relevant treaty to mean a resident income tax purposes of the applicable foreign country, which may require a physical presence within the foreign country such that citizenship or alone may not establish “residency” for purposes of the treaty. (

) Tax treaties reduce the U.S. taxes of residents for foreign countries. With certain exceptions, such as a dual resident individual who is treated as a resident of a foreign country under the tie-breaker rules of an applicable they do not reduce the U.S. taxes of U.S. citizens or resident aliens. U.S. citizens and resident aliens are subject to U.S. income tax on their worldwide income and under a “saving clause” provision in most treaties the U.S. the right to tax its citizens and residents as though the treaty is not in effect (with some exceptions). Caution: “Republic of China”, refers to Taiwan; the U.S. does not have a tax treaty with Taiwan. (
